facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 784 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 784 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 12, 1964 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 157 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 12, 1964 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 157 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 12, 1964 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 157 of 1961. Narsaraju and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. Gopalakrishnan and N. Srinivasan, for the, respondent.

facts.text: Narsaraju and R. N. Sachthey represented the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Narsaraju and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. Gopalakrishnan and N. Srinivasan, for the, respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Gopalakrishnan and N. Srinivasan represented the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan and N. Srinivasan, for the, respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. The respondent-hereinafter called the assessee- carries on the business of manufacture and sale of companyton yarn.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. The respondent-hereinafter called the assessee- carries on the business of manufacture and sale of companyton yarn. In the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1956-57,

facts.text: The assessee carries on the business of manufacture and sale of cotton yarn.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-hereinafter called the assessee- carries on the business of manufacture and sale of companyton yarn. In the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1956-57, the assesses spent Rs. 93,215/- for introduction of Casablanca companyversion system in its spinning plant.

facts.text: In the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1956-57, the assessee spent Rs. 93,215 for introduction of Casablanca conversion system in its spinning plant.

anchor.surface_text: In the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1956-57, the assesses spent Rs. 93,215/- for introduction of Casablanca companyversion system in its spinning plant. Substantially this involved replacement of certain roller stands and fluted rollers fitted 9 5 8 with rubber aprons to the spinning machinery,

facts.text: The expenditure involved replacement of certain roller stands and fluted rollers fitted with rubber aprons to the spinning machinery.

anchor.surface_text: Substantially this involved replacement of certain roller stands and fluted rollers fitted 9 5 8 with rubber aprons to the spinning machinery, removal of ringframes from certain existing parts, introduction, inter alia, of ballbearing jockey-pulleys for companyverting the original band-drivers to tape-drivers and other additions and alterations in the drafting mechanism.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim of Rs. 93,215 because it was not admissible as development rebate since no new machinery was installed.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim of the assessee for Rs. 93,215/- because it was number admissible as development rebate since the introduction of Casablanca companyversion system did number involve installation of new machinery. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer. In appeal to the Appellate Tribunal, besides submitting the claim that expenditure was allowable as development rebate, the assessee urged that the amount laid, out for introducing the Casablanca companyversion system was in any event expenditure allowable under s. 10  2   v  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to the Appellate Tribunal claiming development rebate and alternatively expenditure under s. 10(2)(v).

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Tribunal, besides submitting the claim that expenditure was allowable as development rebate, the assessee urged that the amount laid, out for introducing the Casablanca companyversion system was in any event expenditure allowable under s. 10  2   v  of the Indian Income-tax Act. The Tribunal ins- pected the spinning factory of the assessee and studied the working of the. machinery with the Casablanca companyversion system in the process of spinning yarn.

facts.text: Tribunal inspected the spinning factory of the assessee and studied the working of the machinery with Casablanca conversion system.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal ins- pected the spinning factory of the assessee and studied the working of the. machinery with the Casablanca companyversion system in the process of spinning yarn. They also companysidered the literature published by the manufacturers of Casablanca companyversion system and the relevant numberification issued. by the Ministry of Commerce, Government of India, defining the import policy,

facts.text: Tribunal considered literature by manufacturers and notification by Ministry of Commerce, Government of India on import policy.

anchor.surface_text: They also companysidered the literature published by the manufacturers of Casablanca companyversion system and the relevant numberification issued. by the Ministry of Commerce, Government of India, defining the import policy, and held that as a result of the stress and strain of production over a long period there was need for change in the plant and that the assessee had replaced old parts by introducing the Casablanca companyversion system.

facts.text: Tribunal held that due to stress and strain over long period, assessee replaced old parts with Casablanca conversion system.

anchor.surface_text: and held that as a result of the stress and strain of production over a long period there was need for change in the plant and that the assessee had replaced old parts by introducing the Casablanca companyversion system. In the view of the Tribunal the expenditure incurred for introducing the Casablanca companyversion system,

facts.text: Tribunal held expenditure not admissible as development rebate but admissible as allowance under s. 10(2)(v).

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Tribunal the expenditure incurred for introducing the Casablanca companyversion system, though number admissible as-development rebate, was admissible as an allowance under s. 10  2   v  of the Indian Income-tax Act. The Tribunal then referred the following two questions to the High Court of Judicature at Madras -

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then referred the following two questions to the High Court of Judicature at Madras - Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal had jurisdiction to decide whether the sum of Rs. 93,215/- companystituted an allowable item of expenditure under s. 10 2  v  of the Act ?

facts.text: First question to High Court: Whether Tribunal had jurisdiction to decide if Rs. 93,215 was allowable under s. 10(2)(v).

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal had jurisdiction to decide whether the sum of Rs. 93,215/- companystituted an allowable item of expenditure under s. 10 2  v  of the Act ? Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 93,215/- or any portion thereof is allowable as an expenditure incurred for current repairs under S. 10 2   v  of the Act ?

facts.text: Second question: Whether Rs. 93,215 or portion is allowable as current repairs under s. 10(2)(v).

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 93,215/- or any portion thereof is allowable as an expenditure incurred for current repairs under S. 10 2   v  of the Act ? The High Court accepted the finding recorded by the Tribunal that by the introduction of the Casablanca companyversion system numbernew machinery or plant was installed,

facts.text: High Court accepted Tribunal finding that no new machinery or plant installed by Casablanca system, but fitting of improved minor parts, expenditure revenue nature.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the finding recorded by the Tribunal that by the introduction of the Casablanca companyversion system numbernew machinery or plant was installed, but the introduction of the system amounted to fitting of improved versions of certain minor parts and expenditure in that behalf was of revenue nature.

facts.text: High Court held Tribunal had jurisdiction to permit assessee to raise new contention not raised before departmental authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The High-Court also held that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to permit the assessee to raise a new companytention which was number raised before the departmental authorities. The Commissioner has ,appealed to this Court, with special leave.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner has ,appealed to this Court, with special leave. The Tribunal had evidence before it from which it companyld be companycluded that by introducing the Casablanca companyversion system the assessee made current repairs to the machinery and plant.

facts.text: Tribunal had evidence that introduction of Casablanca system made current repairs to machinery and plant.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had evidence before it from which it companyld be companycluded that by introducing the Casablanca companyversion system the assessee made current repairs to the machinery and plant. The High Court observed that certain moving parts of -the machinery had because of wear and tear to be periodically replaced,

facts.text: High Court observed that certain moving parts had to be periodically replaced due to wear and tear, old type not available, so introduced Casablanca system as modified version.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that certain moving parts of -the machinery had because of wear and tear to be periodically replaced, and when it was found that the old type of replacement parts were number available in the market, the assessee introduced the Casablanca companyversion system, but thereby there was merely replacement of certain parts which were a modified version of the older parts.

facts.text: Counsel for Commissioner did not challenge the findings and High Court answer to second question.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner has number challenged these findings and the answer to the second question recorded in the affirmative by the High Court must be accepted.

arguments.claim: Under s.33(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the Appellate Tribunal is competent to pass such orders on the appeal as it thinks fit; not restricted to questions raised before departmental authorities.

anchor.surface_text: By the first question the jurisdiction of the Tribunal. to allow a plea inconsistent with the plea raised before the departmental authorities is canvassed. Under sub-s.  4  of s. 33 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the Appellate Tribunal is companypetent to pass such orders on the appeal as it thinks fit. There is numberhing in the Income-tax Act which restricts the Tribunal to the determination of questions raised before the departmental authorities.

arguments.claim: All questions whether of law or of fact which relate to the assessment of the assessee may be raised before the Tribunal; duty to grant relief if justified on another ground.

anchor.surface_text: All questions whether of law or of fact which relate to the assessment of the assessee may be raised before the Tribunal. If for reasons recorded by the departmental authorities in rejecting a companytention raised by the assessee, grant of relief to him on another ground is justified, it would be open to the departmental authorities and the Tribunal, and indeed they would be under a duty to grant that relief.

arguments.claim: The subject-matter of the appeal was the right to claim allowance for Rs. 93,215, whether under one head or another of s.10(2); Tribunal had jurisdiction to admit under s.10(2)(v) though not under s.10(2)(vi-b).

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the appeal in the present case was the right of the assessee to claim allowance for Rs. 93,215/-. whether the allowance was admissible under one head or the other of sub-s.  2  of S. 10, the subject-matter for the appeal remained the same, and the Tribunal having held that the expenditure incurred fell within the terms of s. 10 2   v , though number under s. 10 2   vi-b , it had jurisdiction to admit that expenditure as a permissible allowance in the companyputation of the taxable income of the assessee. The High Court was, therefore, right in answering the first question in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of appeal includes all relevant questions of law or fact.
